verses.text: Then Samuel took a flask of oil, poured it on Saul’s head, kissed him, and said, "Has not the LORD anointed you to be ruler over his inheritance?
verses.comment: The Hebrew literally reads 'over his people, over Israel,' but 'his inheritance' remains faithful to the original wording.

verses.text: When you leave me today, you will meet two men near Rachel’s tomb in the territory of Benjamin at Zelzah. They will say to you, 'The donkeys you went to look for have been found. And now your father has stopped worrying about the donkeys and is anxious about you, saying, “What shall I do about my son?”'
verses.comment: Maintains the literal sequence and geographic detail.

verses.text: Then you shall go from there farther and come to the oak of Tabor. Three men going up to God at Bethel will meet you there, one carrying three young goats, another carrying three loaves of bread, and another carrying a skin of wine.
verses.comment: Preserves the Heb. 'oak of Tabor'; some translations have 'plain of Tabor.'

verses.text: They will greet you and give you two loaves of bread, which you will accept from their hand.
verses.comment: Follows Heb. closely; 'give you two loaves of bread from three,' implied from context.

verses.text: After that you will come to Gibeah of God, where there is a garrison of Philistines. As you enter the city, you will meet a group of prophets coming down from the high place with harp, tambourine, flute, and lyre before them, and they will be prophesying.
verses.comment: ‘Garrison of Philistines’ is as in many manuscripts; some Heb. manuscripts lack this phrase.

verses.text: Then the Spirit of the LORD will come upon you mightily, and you will prophesy with them, and you will be changed into a different man.
verses.comment: 'Come upon you mightily' translates the Heb. 'rush upon you.'

verses.text: When these signs happen to you, do whatever your hand finds to do, for God is with you.
verses.comment: 'Do whatever your hand finds to do' is a Hebraic idiom.

verses.text: Go down ahead of me to Gilgal. Then surely I will come down to you to offer burnt offerings and sacrifice peace offerings. Wait seven days until I come to you and show you what you should do.
verses.comment: Accurately reflects instruction and sequence.

verses.text: As Saul turned away to leave Samuel, God gave him another heart. And all these signs came to pass that day.
verses.comment: 'Another heart' meaning God changed his heart.

verses.text: When they came to Gibeah, a group of prophets met him, and the Spirit of God rushed upon him, and he prophesied among them.
verses.comment: 'Rushed upon him' follows Heb. for God's Spirit coming on Saul.

verses.text: When all who knew him before saw him prophesying with the prophets, the people said to one another, 'What has happened to the son of Kish? Is Saul also among the prophets?'
verses.comment: Captures the astonished reaction, as in text.

verses.text: A man from there said, 'And who is their father?' Therefore it became a proverb, 'Is Saul also among the prophets?'
verses.comment: The phrase became proverbial in Israel.

verses.text: When he finished prophesying, he came to the high place.
verses.comment: Simple and direct translation.

verses.text: Saul’s uncle said to him and to his servant, 'Where did you go?' And he said, 'To look for the donkeys. When we saw they were not to be found, we went to Samuel.'
verses.comment: Faithful to conversation sequence.

verses.text: And Saul’s uncle said, 'Please, tell me what Samuel said to you.'
verses.comment: The text recognizes the uncle’s curiosity.

verses.text: Saul said to his uncle, 'He told us plainly that the donkeys had been found.' But about the matter of the kingdom, he did not tell him anything that Samuel had said.
verses.comment: Saul conceals news about the kingship, per Heb. text.

verses.text: Samuel called the people together to the LORD at Mizpah.
verses.comment: Mizpah was a significant meeting place in Israel.

verses.text: He said to the people of Israel, 'This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: I brought Israel out of Egypt, and I rescued you from the hand of the Egyptians and from every kingdom that oppressed you.'
verses.comment: Follows Heb. structure; kingdom refers to oppressors’ rule.

verses.text: But today you have rejected your God, who saves you from all your troubles and your distresses, and you have said to him, 'Set a king over us.' Now therefore present yourselves before the LORD by your tribes and by your clans.
verses.comment: 'Tribes and clans' corresponds to Heb. 'thousands.'

verses.text: So Samuel brought all the tribes of Israel near, and the tribe of Benjamin was chosen by lot.
verses.comment: Casting lots for selection—literal.

verses.text: Then he brought the tribe of Benjamin near by its clans, and the clan of the Matrites was chosen. And Saul the son of Kish was chosen. But when they looked for him, he could not be found.
verses.comment: Matrites: some manuscripts read differently; Heb. text followed.

verses.text: Therefore they inquired of the LORD again, 'Has the man come here?' And the LORD said, 'See, he has hidden himself among the baggage.'
verses.comment: 'Baggage' here means the supplies or equipment of the assembly.

verses.text: So they ran and took him from there. When he stood among the people, he was taller than any of the people from his shoulders upward.
verses.comment: Literally, 'taller than all the people from his shoulders upward.'

verses.text: Samuel said to all the people, 'Do you see the one whom the LORD has chosen? Surely there is no one like him among all the people.' And all the people shouted, 'Long live the king!'
verses.comment: 'Long live the king!' (Heb. 'May the king live!'), a traditional acclamation.

verses.text: Then Samuel told the people the rights and duties of kingship, and wrote them in a scroll and laid it up before the LORD. Then Samuel sent all the people away, each to his home.
verses.comment: 'Laid it up before the LORD' is literal for depositing an official record.

verses.text: Saul also went to his home at Gibeah, and with him went valiant men whose hearts God had touched.
verses.comment: Follows Heb. idiom 'valiant men.'

verses.text: But some worthless men said, 'How can this man save us?' And they despised him and brought him no gift. But he held his peace.
verses.comment: 'Worthless men' translates Heb. 'sons of Belial.' 'Held his peace' means he kept silent.
